items.content_html:
Graphic design is a versatile skill set that extends far beyond the tech world. While many designers aim for jobs at startups or software companies, plenty of industries rely on strong visual communication. If you're looking to expand your job search, consider exploring industries that value design in unique ways.

In this guide, we’ll cover:

  • Industries where graphic design skills are in demand
  • Job titles to look for in different fields
  • Where to find jobs in each industry

Industries That Hire Graphic Designers (Beyond Tech)

1. Advertising & Marketing

This industry thrives on compelling visuals and branding. Companies need designers for ad campaigns, social media graphics, and promotional materials.

Common Job Titles:

  • Marketing Graphic Designer
  • Brand Designer
  • Visual Designer
  • Advertising Designer
  • Social Media Designer
  • Motion Graphics Designer

Where to Find Jobs:

  • AIGA Design Jobs – Listings from top marketing and ad agencies
  • We Work Remotely – Remote marketing design jobs

2. Publishing & Media

Print and digital media companies require designers to create layouts for magazines, newspapers, blogs, and e-books.

Common Job Titles:

  • Editorial Designer
  • Layout Designer
  • Publication Designer
  • Magazine Designer
  • Visual Storyteller

Where to Find Jobs:

  • Mediabistro – Media and publishing job board
  • JournalismJobs.com – Opportunities in print and digital media

3. Retail & E-commerce

Retail brands and online stores rely on graphic designers for product packaging, advertisements, and website visuals.

Common Job Titles:

  • Packaging Designer
  • Retail Graphic Designer
  • E-commerce Visual Designer
  • Merchandising Designer
  • UI/UX Designer
  • Digital Designer

Where to Find Jobs:

  • RetailCareersNow – Retail-specific job listings
  • Shopify Careers – E-commerce jobs, including design roles

4. Healthcare & Pharmaceuticals

Healthcare organizations need design professionals to create educational materials, branding, and digital content for patients and providers.

Common Job Titles:

  • Medical Illustrator
  • Healthcare Graphic Designer
  • Infographic Designer
  • User Experience (UX) Designer

Where to Find Jobs:

  • Health eCareers – Healthcare job listings, including design roles
  • PharmaOpportunities – Jobs in the pharmaceutical industry

5. Education & E-learning

From textbooks to online courses, the education industry relies on design to make information visually engaging.

Common Job Titles:

  • Instructional Designer
  • E-learning Designer
  • Educational Graphic Designer
  • UX/UI Designer

Where to Find Jobs:

  • EdSurge Jobs – EdTech and education job board
  • HigherEdJobs – University and education-related design roles

6. Government & Nonprofits

Public sector organizations and nonprofits need strong design work for campaigns, reports, and outreach programs.

Common Job Titles:

  • Government Graphic Designer
  • Advocacy Visual Designer
  • Nonprofit Communications Designer
  • Brand Strategist

Where to Find Jobs:

  • USAJOBS – Official job board for U.S. government jobs, including design roles
  • Idealist – Nonprofit job board with design opportunities

7. Event & Entertainment Industry

Concerts, sports teams, and entertainment companies all need designers for promotional materials, merchandise, and branding.

Common Job Titles:

  • Event Branding Designer
  • Merchandise Designer
  • Motion Graphics Designer
  • Art Director

Where to Find Jobs:

  • EntertainmentCareers.net – Design jobs in music, film, and sports
  • ShowbizJobs – Jobs in the entertainment industry

8. Finance & Corporate

Banks, investment firms, and corporate organizations need graphic designers for branding, reports, and marketing materials.

Common Job Titles:

  • Corporate Graphic Designer
  • Financial Infographic Designer
  • Presentation Designer
  • Visual Designer

Where to Find Jobs:

  • eFinancialCareers – Finance industry jobs, including design roles
  • LinkedIn Jobs – Corporate design roles at major companies

How to Transition Into a New Industry as a Graphic Designer

If you want to move into one of these industries, here are a few steps to help:

Customize Your Portfolio – Showcase work that aligns with the industry’s needs (e.g., healthcare-related infographics for a hospital job).

Use Industry-Specific Keywords – Tailor your resume and LinkedIn profile to include terms relevant to the industry (e.g., "instructional design" for education jobs).

Network & Reach Out – Connect with industry professionals on LinkedIn and attend niche industry events.

Freelance or Volunteer – If you lack experience in a specific industry, take on freelance projects or volunteer work to build relevant portfolio pieces.

Final Thoughts

Graphic design skills are valuable across many industries. By broadening your job search beyond tech and targeting industries like healthcare, education, or entertainment, you can unlock exciting career opportunities. The key is to tailor your portfolio, use industry-specific language, and actively network in your chosen field.

If you're looking for your next graphic design job, start exploring different industries today—you might find a perfect fit where you least expect it.

items.title: How to Land a UX Design Internship

items.content_html:
How to Land a UX Design Internship: A Guide for Students and Early Professionals

Breaking into UX design can be exciting but also challenging, especially when you're just starting out. A UX design internship is a great way to gain real-world experience, build a strong portfolio, and kick-start your career in the tech industry. But with so much competition, how can you stand out? This guide will walk you through the key steps to landing your first UX design internship.

1. Build a Strong UX Portfolio (Even Without Experience)

Your portfolio is your ticket to an internship. But what if you don’t have real-world projects yet? No worries—there are other ways to showcase your skills:

  • Case Studies on Personal or Concept Projects: Redesign an existing app, improve a website’s user experience, or create a new product from scratch.

  • Hackathons & Design Challenges: Participate in online hackathons or take part in daily UX/UI design challenges on platforms like Dribbble or Behance.

  • Volunteer Work: Offer to design for a nonprofit or a small business to gain practical experience.

  • Document Your Process: Employers want to see your design thinking. Show your research, wireframes, and iterations—not just final visuals.

2. Optimize Your Resume for UX Internship Applications

A UX design resume should highlight your skills, projects, and ability to think like a designer. Here’s what to focus on:

  • Tailored Experience: Include relevant coursework, personal projects, or any freelance UX work.

  • Skills & Tools: Mention UX research, wireframing, prototyping, usability testing, and tools like Figma, Adobe XD, and Sketch.

  • Education & Certifications: If you’re taking a UX bootcamp, online courses (such as Google UX Design Certificate), or college classes, include them.

  • Keywords for ATS Optimization: Many companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) to scan resumes. Use keywords from job descriptions, such as "user research," "interaction design," or "prototyping."

3. Create an Online Presence to Boost Your Visibility

Companies often look beyond resumes and portfolios. Here’s how to strengthen your online presence:

  • LinkedIn Profile: Optimize your LinkedIn with UX-related keywords, list relevant projects, and engage with UX content.

  • Dribbble/Behance Profile: Upload your best work to showcase your visual design skills.

  • Medium or Blog: Writing about UX topics, case studies, or design principles can position you as a thoughtful designer.

4. Network & Find UX Internship Opportunities

Networking can help you uncover hidden UX internship opportunities. Try these strategies:

  • Join UX Communities: Engage with groups on LinkedIn, Slack, and Discord (e.g., Design Buddies, UX Mastery).

  • Attend UX Meetups & Webinars: Events hosted by organizations like AIGA, IDF, or local UX groups are great for meeting industry professionals.

  • Reach Out to UX Designers: Message UX professionals on LinkedIn to ask about their career journey or for portfolio feedback.

  • Follow UX Internship Job Boards: Check sites like LinkedIn Jobs, Indeed, Internships.com, and AngelList.

5. Prepare for UX Internship Interviews

Once you land an interview, preparation is key. Expect to discuss:

  • Your Portfolio: Walk through your case studies, explaining your design decisions, research, and outcomes.

  • UX Design Process: Be ready to talk about how you approach user research, wireframing, prototyping, and usability testing.

  • Problem-Solving Scenarios: Interviewers may present design challenges. Practice thinking out loud and explaining your thought process.

  • Soft Skills & Collaboration: UX design is teamwork-heavy. Show that you can work with developers, PMs, and stakeholders effectively.

Final Thoughts

Landing a UX design internship takes persistence, but with the right strategy, you can make it happen. Build a strong portfolio, optimize your resume, network with professionals, and prepare for interviews. Even if you don’t have direct experience, showcase your design thinking and passion for UX.

By following these steps, you’ll be well on your way to securing your first UX design internship—and setting yourself up for a successful career in user experience design!

items.title: How to Secure a Remote Product Design Job in Tech
items.summary: Remote product design jobs offer incredible opportunities to work on digital experiences, collaborate with cross-functional teams, and contribute to innovative products—all from anywhere in the world. However, landing a remote role in product design is competitive. You need to showcase not only your design skills…
items.content_html:
Remote product design jobs offer incredible opportunities to work on digital experiences, collaborate with cross-functional teams, and contribute to innovative products—all from anywhere in the world. However, landing a remote role in product design is competitive. You need to showcase not only your design skills but also your ability to solve user problems and drive business impact. In this post, we'll go over some ways to optimize your application and portfolio to stand out.

Optimizing Your Resume for Product Design Jobs in Tech

Tech companies look for product designers who understand user experience, research, and business objectives. Your resume should highlight these aspects effectively:

  • Emphasize UX/UI and Product Thinking: Showcase experience designing intuitive user interfaces, wireframes, and interactive prototypes.

  • Use Impact-Driven Bullet Points: Rather than listing responsibilities, demonstrate impact. Example: “Redesigned checkout flow, reducing drop-off rates by 25%.”

  • Highlight Research & User-Centered Design: Mention experience conducting user research, usability testing, and A/B testing.

  • Technical & Tool Proficiency: List skills in Figma, Sketch, Adobe XD, and prototyping tools like Framer or Principle.

  • Collaboration & Communication: Product designers work closely with engineers, PMs, and researchers. Showcase cross-functional collaboration skills.

  • Keyword Optimization: Include relevant terms like "product design," "UX/UI design," "user research," and "interaction design" to optimize for Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS).

Optimizing Your Portfolio for a Remote Product Design Job

A strong portfolio is critical for product design roles. Here’s how to make yours compelling for tech recruiters:

  • Tell a Story with Case Studies: Structure projects using the problem-solution-impact format to demonstrate how your design decisions solved user and business problems.

  • Prioritize UX & User Research: Include wireframes, user journey maps, and research insights to show your problem-solving approach.

  • Show Prototypes & Interactive Demos: If possible, include links to Figma prototypes or animations that showcase interactions.

  • Highlight Key Metrics: If your design improved conversion rates, engagement, or retention, include those numbers.

  • Optimize for SEO: Use keywords like "best product design portfolio," "UX case studies," and "remote product design work" to enhance search visibility.

  • Keep It Clean & Easy to Navigate: Recruiters skim portfolios quickly, so a minimalist, intuitive layout is key.

What If You Don’t Have Strong Metrics?

If you lack direct impact metrics, here’s what you can do:

  • Use Qualitative Insights: Highlight user feedback, usability test results, or client testimonials.

  • Leverage Side Projects or Redesigns: Show how you would improve an existing product’s UX, even if it’s not from a paid role.

  • Focus on Process Over Outcomes: Explain your design thinking, user research approach, and iteration process.

  • Gather Endorsements: Recommendations from colleagues or clients can be just as valuable as hard numbers.

Final Thoughts on Landing a Remote Product Design Job

Securing a remote product design job in tech requires a strategic approach. Optimize your resume with impact-driven bullet points, craft a compelling portfolio that highlights user research and design decisions, and showcase your problem-solving skills. Even if you don’t have impressive metrics, focus on qualitative insights and storytelling. With persistence and a strong application, you’ll be on your way to a rewarding remote product design career.

However, the job market is tough and the competition is fierce. Many companies also have return to office orders, causing the availblity of remote roles to…
items.content_html:
Remote graphic design jobs offer the perfect blend of creativity, flexibility, and lucrative opportunities, especially within the tech industry. However, the job market is tough and the competition is fierce. Many companies also have return to office orders, causing the availblity of remote roles to be more scarce. If you want to land a remote role at a tech company, your resume and portfolio must be optimized for success. This guide will help you craft an application that stands out, leveraging industry best practices and ATS keyword-friendly strategies.

Optimizing Your Resume for Remote Graphic Design Jobs in Tech

Tech companies value results, problem-solving, and adaptability. Your resume should reflect these qualities with a clean, structured format and data-backed achievements. Here’s what to focus on:

  • Tailored Experience: Highlight design work relevant to tech, such as UI/UX projects, mobile app design, SaaS branding, and website interfaces.
  • Impact-Driven Bullet Points: Use measurable results to showcase your contributions. Instead of saying, “Designed landing pages,” say, “Designed conversion-optimized landing pages that increased sign-ups by 30%.”
  • Technical Skills & Design Tools: List proficiency in essential tools like Figma, Sketch, Adobe Creative Suite, and no-code platforms like Webflow or Framer.
  • Collaboration & Communication: Remote work requires seamless communication. Highlight your experience working with cross-functional teams, including developers, marketers, and product managers, across different time zones.
  • Keyword Optimization for ATS: Many tech companies use Applicant Tracking Systems (ATS) to filter resumes. Use relevant keywords from job descriptions—such as "remote graphic designer," "UI/UX design," or "web design"—to increase your chances of passing ATS scans.

Creating a Standout Graphic Design Portfolio for Tech Companies

Your portfolio is your ultimate proof of expertise. Here’s how to ensure it’s optimized for tech job opportunities:

  • Showcase Problem-Solving Skills: Tech companies value designers who can think strategically. Structure your case studies using the problem-solution-impact format to demonstrate your design thinking approach.
  • Keep It Concise & Visually Engaging: Recruiters scan quickly. A clutter-free, intuitive layout with high-quality visuals is key.
  • Highlight Metrics Where Possible: If your work led to increased engagement, conversions, or retention, mention it with concrete data. Example: "Redesigned an e-commerce site, resulting in a 25% increase in checkout completion rate."
  • Demonstrate Range & Specialization: Show versatility in design styles while emphasizing a niche—such as SaaS UI/UX, mobile app interfaces, or branding for tech startups.
  • Optimize for SEO: Use keywords like "best graphic design portfolio for tech jobs," "remote UI/UX designer portfolio," and "modern web design showcase" to make your portfolio searchable.
  • Include a Personal Touch: Add a short about section explaining your design philosophy, what excites you about working in tech, and links to your LinkedIn or Dribbble profile.

What If You Don’t Have Strong Metrics?

Not every designer has access to performance analytics. If you lack hard metrics, here’s what to do:

  • Use Alternative Indicators: If you don’t have conversion rates, showcase usability feedback, engagement improvements, or client testimonials.
  • Leverage Personal Projects: Showcase self-initiated projects that solve real-world problems. Mock redesigns of existing tech products (e.g., "How I Would Redesign Spotify's Mobile App") can make a great addition.
  • Gather Testimonials: Positive feedback from clients, employers, or colleagues can be just as persuasive as metrics.
  • Focus on Your Design Process: Detail your design thinking approach, user research methodologies, and the rationale behind your design choices.

Final Thoughts on Landing a Remote Graphic Design Job in Tech

Breaking into the tech industry as a remote graphic designer requires a strategic approach. Optimize your resume and portfolio to highlight problem-solving skills, measurable impact, and adaptability. If you lack hard metrics, focus on storytelling, case studies, and client feedback. With a well-crafted application and persistence, you’ll be well on your way to landing a high-paying remote graphic design job in tech.
